summary:
Hoi!

Als schrijfster & storyteller kun je mij zien als een gids in het vinden van de juiste woorden. Ik wijs je op het verhaal dat je wilt delen. Zo kun jij vanuit een sterk basisvertrouwen een krachtige boodschap uitdragen.

Daar kom je wanneer je bewust van bent dat je: 

op dit moment niet de juiste woorden kan vinden voor jouw aanbod. Je weet dat de juiste informatie echt verschil kan maken. Ook is voor jou duidelijk waar je over een jaar wilt staan en hoe je je onderneming wilt  laten groeien. Je bent net als ik ondernemend en graag in ontwikkeling.

Je hebt een product of idee voor jouw onderneming, maar de vertaling ervan naar een kloppend verhaal is niet jouw expertise. Je richt je aandacht op datgene wat je motiveert om je bedrijf te runnen. Het vinden van de juiste woorden besteed je liever uit, zodat je ook hierin kwaliteit kan waarborgen.

In de communicatie die je voor ogen hebt wil je in fijne en kloppende bewoordingen vermelden waar je product of aanbod over gaat. Hierdoor weten ook jouw klanten wat ze kunnen verwachten en waar ze aan toe zijn. Jouw aanbod krijgt de aandacht die het verdiend.

Jouw visie zorgt soms voor enige ruis in je plannen, want in de toekomst is er nu eenmaal veel mogelijk. Ordenen en helderheid geven dan een rustpunt. Samen kom ik met jou tot de kern van je product of aanbod, zodat de prioriteit duidelijk is. Putten uit de bron van wat je drijft is dan een uitkomst. Of zoals een klant mij teruggaf:

â€œJij helpt mij buiten het vinden van de juiste woorden, steeds weer met het oppakken van de draad. Dit door mij te wijzen op het verhaal dat ik wil delen.â€ 

Hoe dit tot stand komt? Dat leg ik je graag uit in vier stappen:

1) Eerst gaan we het idee voor je product of aanbod onderzoeken.
â†’ Uit je hoofd in je ondernemershart!

2) Na dit onderzoek zorg ik voor een woordenplan: 
â†’ Dit geeft overzicht en helderheid.

3) Ik bouw jouw verhaal op. Verwerk eventuele feedback. Check, check, dubbelcheck.
â†’ Is dit de boodschap die je voor ogen had? Wat is nog nodig?

4) Het verhaal is nu klaar om online te presenteren.
â†’ Jij kunt nu jouw aanbod zichtbaar maken voor jouw potentiÃ«le klanten.

Wil je meer weten over mij of mijn werk? Neem dan zeker een kijkje op: dewoordenvrouw.nl

Bericht of bel me gerust als je benieuwd bent naar een samenwerking:
âœ‰ info@dewoordenvrouw.nl
âœ† 06 51824013

Hartelijks,
Nineke
-De Woordenvrouw

^_^ Als gids vang ik jouw verhaal in woorden vanuit een vrouwelijke essentie: zo bekrachtig ik jouw zakelijke missie.

skills: ['Research', 'Teacher Training', 'Leadership', 'Management', 'Higher Education', 'Personal Development', 'Qualitative Research', 'Organizational Development', 'Training', 'Lecturing']
summary:
Annemarie Neeleman MA is an educational researcher and policy advisor. In the summer of 2013, she joined a research project at Maastricht University on the long-range educational research agenda for the Dutch province of Limburg. In this project, an active dialogue between educational research and educational practice is the starting point of all activities. In 2014 â€“ fascinated by the interplay between educational research, policy making, and practice â€“ she started a PhD research into the actual use of school autonomy. Annemarie studies school intervention decisions by Dutch secondary education school leaders, the accompanying considerations, and the research used in the decision-making process. Her first article on the construction of an empirically based classification scheme of school interventions has been published in the Journal of Educational Change (open access). She will defend her dissertation in June 2019.

Annemarie is a policy advisor for schools, school boards, intermediary organisations, and local and national authorities alike. She specializes in qualitative and quantitative analysis of complex educational organisations, quality management, professional learning networks, evidence-based leadership, professionalisation projects, and international comparisons. Annemarie publishes on all before mentioned topics in academic and professional journals and books, in both English and Dutch. She performs regularly at national and international conferences. Currently, Annemarie is senior policy advisor at CVO Rotterdam, a large secondary school board in greater Rotterdam, and editor-in-chief of the professional journal 'SchoolManagement'.

summary:
Ronald A. Halim is a transport and logistics specialist with more than 12 years experience in  quantitative policy analysis. Ronald has had the experience of working in private, public, academic sectors, as well as intergovernmental organization. 
Currently, he serves as the founder of an independent advisory company: Equitable Maritime Consulting where he also works as the principal transport economist. 

He is authors and co-authors of the following reports:
1. UNCTADâ€™s Impact Assessment on IMO short-term measures. The report is submitted to the IMOâ€™s 76th MEPC to help conclude the adoption of the goal-based short term measures at the IMO. EMC provides assessment on the Value of Time for globally traded commodities to support assessing the impact of shipâ€™s speed reduction on trade logistics costs and economies of countries. EMC also carries out a comprehensive case study for selected developing countries.

2. Developing a global transport costs dataset for international trade
EMC supports the development of the first international transport costs database that are disaggregated by 4 major transport modes (air, maritime, road, and rail), covering trade records of 5000+ HS-6 commodities, across 119 countries. The project is a joint collaboration with UNCTAD. (the report of this project is submitted as IMO doc. ISWG GHG 7/8)
https://unctad.org/system/files/official-document/ser-rp-2022d5_en.pdf

3. the World Bank report: "Understanding the Economic Impacts of Greenhouse Gas Mitigation Policies on Shipping : What Is the State of the Art of Current Modeling Approaches?"
http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/215561546957017567/Understanding-the-Economic-Impacts-of-Greenhouse-Gas-Mitigation-Policies-on-Shipping-What-Is-the-State-of-the-Art-of-Current-Modeling-Approaches

4. Action Programme on Intermodal Freight Transport in Java, Indonesia
https://changing-transport.org/wp-content/uploads/2021_Action-Programme-on-Intermodal-Freight-Transport-in-Java-Indonesia-1.pdf

Ronald obtained his doctoral degree in modeling global container transport from Delft University and Technology and he holds MSc in Systems Engineering, Policy Analysis, and Management from Delft University of Technology with a specialization in modeling and simulation. Ronald is specialized in transport demand forecasting, design of large-scale multi-modal network, predictive analytics, optimization models, data visualization, and data science techniques. He is an avid user of open source tools, platforms and libraries such as Java, Python and R with more than 9 years of experience.

I have worked in Africa, Latin America & Europe (UN, Ministries, research centres, NGOs, and private sector) as a development specialist (MSc) on malaria, public health, education, information management, gender issues, agriculture, and participatory community development and developed and managed international multi-stakeholder projects with a focus on Africa. I have broad multicultural, interdisciplinary experience at different levels, from grassroots to policy, and therewith ample experience to work efficiently and tactically in a complex environment.

I am the co-founder of MalariaWorld: the worldâ€™s largest, free online knowledge platform for malaria professionals with >10.000 members in 140 countries.  I am proud of the fact that in 2015 MalariaWorld received the Social Media Heroes Award Best Online Communications, supported by the World Health Organization. 

I am the co-owner of K&S Consulting (with Bart Knols, PhD MBA  https://www.linkedin.com/in/bartknols/). K&S Consulting is a small, agile and flexible consulting firm that celebrates its 10th anniversary this year (2017). We have undertaken consultancy work for major organisations like the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, but also Ministries, African science organizations, and the private sector (Bayer AG, Tropicare, Glaxo Smith Kline, e.g.).  We have worked for the EU (FP7), the United Nations (WHO, UNEP, UNESCO), and between us share more than 20 years of working and living in developing countries, notably in East- and Southern Africa. We combine expertise and experience in the natural and social sciences, and have experience with NWO grants (WOTRO, VIDI) and served on several of its review and evaluation panels.

I work at IHE Delft Institute for Water Education as an Associate Professor.

I have research interests in using systems thinking and modelling to explore water systems, and their link to food and energy systems at a range of scales, and the implications of these interactions for policy. I have interests in global hydrology and water resources, and the impact of climate and social changes on water availability for human consumption. I am also interested in the relationships between water and energy in urban areas. I am developing an interest into how the burgeoning global urban population will be supplied with sufficient water, and how various technical and social measures may be applied to reduce demand and/or increase supply, and how we can most efficiently use resources to supply water to this growing population.

In addition to my main research interests in water systems, I have expertise and interests in 2D flood modelling, risk analysis, catchment evolution to widespread perturbation, sediment flux from continents, sedimentology, volcanology and geomorphology.

Hello everyone, I'm Ana, a master's student diving into Economic & Consumer Psychology at Leiden University. Here's a little sneak peek into my journey so far:

ğŸŒ± After graduating in Business Psychology, I delved into some fascinating subjects â€” like the links between our decision-making tendencies and our overall happiness. It amazes me what our minds can reveal!

ğŸŒ± Jump to the present: Here I am in the lovely Netherlands, excited to embark on my MSc journey. And why consumer psychology? To put it simply, I'm drawn to understanding the daily choices we all make and the motivations behind them.

ğŸŒ± My latest aspiration? Merging my understanding of CX with product management. With so much to learn, I can't wait to connect dots, innovate, and shape products that truly resonate with people.

summary:
Peter Beentjes:  'Geloof in wie je bent'
Zelf ben ik nooit gestimuleerd in het ontdekken van mijn talenten. "Vroeger was ik zoâ€™n kwetsbare jongere. Klein zelfbeeld, ik geloofde niet in mezelf en wist niet eens dat ik talenten had." Na een bijzondere gebeurtenis en radicale keuze ben ik een andere weg ingegaan. Een weg die gepaard ging met veel vallen en opstaan maar mijn stoutste dromen zijn uitgekomen en het was nooit saai.

 "Daarom vind ik het belangrijk om in anderen te investeren met het vinden van hun talent."

Je bent bijzonder en uniek:

Er is er maar een van u op de wereld en als het goed is: een authentiek en compleet mens in balans, Helaas ziet men zichzelf niet altijd als een prachtig juweel, maar waar anderen in u een ruwe steen zien, en waar die steen bewerkt wordt met liefde, geduld en vakmanschap, dan ontstaat er een schitterende diamant.

Mijn inspiratie:

De film The Butterfly Circus met Nick Vujicic. 

Een negentien minuten durende film 
Daarom is mijn missie:

In de blauwdruk van ieders DNA staan al onze talenten beschreven en zijn bij iedereen aanwezig. We mogen elkaar helpen om die talenten te vinden en ze te activeren. Samen gaan we opzoek naar uw talent en die te voeden met enthousiasme en doorzettingsvermogen en waardoor u uw stoutste dromen kunt laten uitkomen.

summary:
As a web accessibility enthusiast, I am passionate about contributing to digital inclusion. 

With over 5 years of experience as a client and contractor, I can help improve your digital accessibility by:

- Assessing your digital products for accessibility issues
- Providing consultation on how to solve these issues
- Creating evaluation reports as per WCAG 2.1 AA Conformance
- Interpreting relevant legislation and creating an action plan to ensure compliance

My knowledge includes:

- WCAG guidelines
- Section 508 Standards for Web
- Assistive technologies such as screen readers NVDA, JAWS, TalkBack, and VoiceOver
- Tools like ANDI, WAVE, AXE, Chrome DevTools, and CCA (Color Contrast Analyzer)

I can suggest remediation to fix accessibility issues and have experience in:

- Software development and manual testing for web and mobile applications
- Test case execution, bug report creation, defect analysis, functional, exploratory, cross-browser testing, and regression testing

I have worked with clients in various industries, including healthcare, education, media and entertainment, retail, tours and travel, and financial services.

I am committed to further embedding digital accessibility in your organization and can help you draw up an action plan to become more accessible. 

If you're interested in improving your digital accessibility, feel free to get in touch!

name: Alexandra Corcode
skills: ['Social Media Marketing', 'Social Media', 'Management', 'Digital Communication', 'Design', 'Creative Problem Solving', 'Adobe Photoshop', 'Documentary Photography', 'Adobe Premiere Pro']
summary:
Alexandra Corcode (b.2000), is a Romanian Documentary Photographer based between The Netherlands and Romania.

Her work focuses on themes of immigration, loneliness, death, lost traditions, mental and physical deterioration and the traces of human absence. Much of her practice is focused on capturing the unseen communities in her country. She continues to document the life of her family and low-income communities, in her home country of Romania.

In 2021 she participated in the VII Academy 9 month long programme in documentary and narrative practice. This year she has been published in Reuve 6 Mois - La Revue de Photojournalisme and has been selected for the New York Times Portfolio Review. In 2019 she was the recipient of the Licart portrait award and was a finalist for the Siena International Photo Award.


Alexandra is currently undertaking a BA in Photography at the Royal Academy of Art in The Hague (KABK). She is also available for commissions in Romania, The Netherlands and internationally.

name: Paschalis Pechlivanis
position 1: Assistant Professor in History of International Relations
skills: ['Research', 'Policy Analysis', 'International Relations', 'Political Science', 'Politics', 'Qualitative Research', 'Social Sciences', 'Human Rights', 'International Security', 'Foreign Policy', 'Academic Writing', 'Policy', 'European Union', 'International History', 'Diplomatic History', 'US Foreign Policy', 'Cold War']
summary:
Dr. Paschalis Pechlivanis is Assistant Professor in History of International Relations at the Department of History and Art History, Utrecht University. His research interests lie at the intersection of International History and International Relations, with a specific focus on the Cold War, US Foreign Policy and post-1945 European and Balkan History. His monograph 'America and Romania in the Cold War: A Differentiated DÃ©tente, 1969-80' (A Romanian edition of the book is forthcoming by Editura Litera) examines the US foreign policy of differentiation towards the socialist regimes of Eastern Europe as it was implemented by various administrations towards Ceausescuâ€™s Romania from 1969 to 1980. Dr. Pechlivanis is currently developing his next project "A Cold War Microcosm: The Balkans from 1945 to 1989".

He studied Law (LLB) at Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (2009), International Relations (MScEcon, Distinction) at Aberystwyth University (2012) and he obtained his PhD in History from the European University Institute (EUI), Florence in 2017. During his PhD he has been a visiting researcher at New York University and he has previously taught at the University of Florence, Italy.

Radu Stefan. In 2006 Alina Tarau started working on the Ph.D. thesis "Model-Based Control for Postal Automation and Baggage Handling". This research has been performed under the supervision of Prof.dr.ir. Hans Hellendoorn and Prof.dr.ir. Bart De Schutter. During her Ph.D. research (2006-2010), Alina Tarau also obtained the DISC certificate for fulfilling the course program requirements of the Dutch Institute for Systems and Control. Currently she is with ASML,  Veldhoven.

summary:
Stijn van der Krogt is an energetic and inspiring person. He has 30 years of academic and professional  experience in business and development in Africa and Latin America. He is specialized in strategy development, entrepreneurship and social innovation and digital transformation.
Between 1997 and 2012 he worked as Director Country Programs at the International Institute for Communication and Development in the Netherlands, managing over 120 ICT for development policies and programs implemented in collaboration with government agencies, SMEs, NGOs and grass root organizations in 15 countries in Africa and Latin America.
Since 2012 he is Director of Changing Values International, advisory company that supports governments and SMEs in developing countries in strategic development and project implementation. In Haiti CVI advised the government on the ICT for education strategy as a senior consultant for the Inter-American Development Bank. In Bolivia CVI supported the departmental government of Santa Cruz and cooperatives in the development of ICT platforms and services for education and agribusiness development. In Paraguay the company advised and trained over 100 SMEs on innovation and business development. 
Between 2014 and 2021 he developed and managed the Faculty of Business Sciences as Dean of the Faculty of Business Administration of the Universidad Paraguayo Alemana in close collaboration with the SRH Higher Education in Germany and the Paraguayan Industrial Employers Union. From 2020 to early 2023 he has worked on the development of the Haarlem Institute of Higher Education, a joint venture of SRH Higher Education and the Global School for Entrepreneurship, where he was responsible for the development and management of bachelor and master programs, applied research and collaboration with the private sector. 
Currently he works as Chief Internationalization Officer at SRH Higher Education and responsible for the development of new SRH international campuses and academic programs outside Germany. 
He is also a visiting Professor a various universities on social business, business informatics, entrepreneurship, management & leadership and publishes with international colleagues on various themes such as  internationalization of high-tech companies, platform-based business, business intelligence, fintech and entrepreneurship and recently about green and digital innovation.

name: Julienne Weegels
skills: ['Human Rights Research', 'University Teaching', 'Lecturing', 'Workshops', 'Latin American Studies', 'Violence', 'Prisons', 'Ethnography', 'Gender Studies', 'Anthropology', 'Creative Writing', 'Qualitative Research']
summary:
I'm assistant professor of Latin American Studies at the University of Amsterdam - Centre for Latin American Research and Documentation (CEDLA). Trained as an anthropologist, I'm specialized in ethnographic research on violence, (dis)order, (prison) governance and state-(un)making, particularly in Nicaragua. Currently I also work on these topics in the city of Amsterdam, as PI on the research project "Het Ongelijkheidsbeginsel" (the principle of inequality), which takes a holistic approach to understand the ways in which urban inequalities (spatial, socio-economic and racial/ethnic) are mitigated and/or reproduced through criminal justice interventions.

At the same time, I continue to research practices of (para-)policing, imprisonment, state crime and organized crime in Nicaragua. In relation to the 2018 protests and their aftermath, I work with (former) political prisoners and their family members, Nicaraguan exiles and refugees, and human rights activists. I am currently working on two book projects. The first is a volume co-edited with Hanneke Stuit and Jennifer Turner, which is titled "Carceral Worlds" (Bloomsbury). The book critically explores the expansion of carcerality in our globalized present and how this may be unsettled. The second is a manuscript based on my doctoral thesis, which was awarded a cum laude distinction. The thesis, "Performing Prison: Power, Agency and Co-Governance in Nicaraguan Prisons", was based on 31 months of multi-sited ethnographic research conducted between 2009 and 2016 with long and short-sentenced (former) prisoners of three Nicaraguan prison facilities. This book is about the ways in which prisoners negotiate power both inside and outside their cells, documenting and theorizing the emergence of Nicaragua's hybrid carceral state.

In general, I am interested in the day-to-day workings of prison life and the (development) of carceral/penal states, policing and other forms of non-state/extralegal surveillance and governance. In doing so, I focus on questions of (il)legitimacy, violence and the body. I participate actively in a number of interdisciplinary networks on confinement and prisons research, including the Global Prisons Research Network (as a co-organizer), the EASA Anthropology of Confinement Network (co-convener 2018-2022), and the Americas Prisons Research Network/Red Penitenciaria de las Americas (founding member), with whom I organize various events. 

I'm always open to collaborations and exchanging ideas. Feel free to write me at j.h.j.weegels@uva.nl. Take care!

In her work she bring these worlds together. Her vocal style has been influenced by Afro-American and African music traditions, giving her a truly unique sound.Her music is comforting and has a thread of strong social consciousness running through it. Her song â€œMinorityâ€ garnered two nominations at the Namibian Annual Music Awards. She has also been credited with a host of awards, both locally and internationally. In 2014, she was a finalist in the prestigious Radio France International Discovery Awards.

During her career, Shishani has performed in the Netherlands, Germany, France, Germany, Czech Republic, Poland, Ireland, Greece, Italy, India, Malawi, Morocco, Kenya, South Africa, and her twin homes, Belgium and Namibia.

Shishani has also spearheaded various arts initiatives in Namibia focusing on social upliftment. She is a founder of ARTNAM; advocating for the promotion of Namibian arts.

In her work as an anthropologist / musicologist she has specialised in contemporary urban Namibian music. Currently she is writing for the Bloomsbury Encyclopaedia of Contemporary Music of the World.  


Shishani means â€˜crownâ€™ in Oshiwambo, one of Namibia's native languages.

Prab Laoharojanaphan is a communication strategist with 9 years of experiences in Thai politics. His recent works include a communication director for Mr. Chadchart Sittipuntâ€™s Bangkok gubernatorial election, winning the biggest landslide in Bangkokâ€™s election history, and a general manager leading strategic communication team at Pheu Thai Party in which he supervised the first major rebranding in 14 years of the partyâ€™s history. 

Since 2013, he has been in the leadership of planning and implementation of communication strategies for the well-orchestrated political campaigns in Thailandâ€™s general elections. Prab has also contributed his skills to advocacy projects related to social activisms and civil society such as a digital archive of 6 October 1976 massacre (www.doct6.com), and founded Rethink Thailand, an initiative to help academics and NGOs making infographic animations about social issues.

Prior to his career, Prab became a student activist after the Thai military cracked down on the United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship (UDD) protests in May 2010. The student organization he founded, League of Liberal Thammasat for Democracy (LLTD), had been recognized for an early effective use of social media for political campaigns. While he was a 4th year student in 2013, he was recruited to work as a social media manager for Bangkok gubernatorial election campaign of Pheu Thai Partyâ€™s candidate Pol.Gen. Pongsapat Pongcharoen. After graduation, Prab continued his path of communication strategist with Pheu Thai Party and Yingluck Shinawatraâ€™s government until the military coup occurred in May 2014.

Prab studied integrative business management at Thammasat University, Bangkok (BBA in 2013) and studied a master degree in communication and information sciences with specialization human aspects of information technology at Tilburg University, the Netherlands (MSc in 2017). 

In addition to political-related works, Prabâ€™s interdisciplinary experiences in communication strategy and data science has been recognized as one of his core competencies. He is currently an adjunct faculty member at Thammasat Business School and a senior data scientist at Voice TV. In January 2019, he led the creation of data science and machine learning course at Thammasat Business School, the first machine learning course ever created at any Thailandâ€™s business schools.

Transport economist with more than 40 years of experience in consulting and research over a broad range of transport fields and projects related to shipping, ports, inland transport modes such as railways, road and inland waterways, combined transportation and logistics and related developments of quantitative models and computer programs.

I did/participated in a great number of economic and financial evaluations of projects in the logistics and transport sector all over the world, projects funded by the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and bi-lateral aid. Studies on port competition concerned West Europe, the Mediterranean, the Middle East, South East Asia, Africa and the Caribbean. From 2000 to 2003 I gave courses on maritime economics in the framework of MEL at the Erasmus University.

In the period of 1970 â€“ 1974 I participated in three long-term forecast studies (with a time horizon up to the year 2000!) which are interesting from a historic, philosophical point of view, viz. 
(1) Netherlands Integral Traffic and Transport study,

summary:
NATALIA SISTO 
Sculptor, internationally recognized artist. Of Italian and Spanish origins. 
With her extensive career in art, she has been living in Europe for more than 22 years. Her sculpture work is part of collections, museums, facades, monuments, private commissions and public entities. She has developed large-scale projects and has worked and exhibited in Argentina, Ecuador, Spain, Italy, France, Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands. 
Today Natalia continues to develop what she calls her vibrational realism, an innovative concept in art and writing her book â€œLiberArteâ€. She is also chairman of the AWAKE foundation. 
--
Natalia Sisto was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on February the 17th. 1977. 
She studied at the school of Arts Prilidiano PueyredÃ³n, today National Institute of Art UNA, between 1994 and 1999. At the end of her degree, she made the postgrade course in Postgrade Direction of Visuals Arts Ernesto CÃ¡rcova until 2001.
In 1995 she travelled for the first time to Europe to pursue her life-search within creative art and  all sentient knowledge inherent to human beings.
In 1999 began working with her Master, D. Mariano PagÃ©s on the monument to Carlos Gardel, who taught her everyday and developed her love for sculpture.
At the end of the year, D. Enzo Bianchi comissioned her first sculpture, in which she imprinted her meaning of the realization of shared dreams.
In early 2001 she moved to Spain, where she lives still. Natalia has also lived in Madrid, Barcelona and Galicia. And worked with several Spanish sculptors on different projects throughout both Europe and America; generating fruitful creative experience. During this time, in 2006, she established her studio in the village of ChinchÃ³n, Madrid.
Since then, she has achieved several significant assignments, including a collection of sculptures that preside over the front of the building - Edifici Emperadriu Eugenia - in Monturiol, Barcelona. She has exhibited her art works in Argentina, Italy and Spain. 
Nataliaâ€™s highly original creative style is best described as figurative realism with a strong innovative concept.

Specialties: Sculpture/ART - 3 Dimensiones

summary:
Growing up in the international capital of peace and justice and I started my interest in the international community from an early age. After completing high school, I worked in the hospitality branch with Mise en Place. Here, I had the opportunity to attend international conferences and diplomatic events as a garcon. This further inspired me to join this community. 

Therefore, I opted for the program of European Studies at the The Hague University of Applied Sciences. This program is a wide-ranging course that provides students with the know-how to become European professionals. During this program, I gained skills ranging from political science to marketing. 
As an extracurricular activity, I joined the international organization of Enactus where I have developed a social enterprise that had the aim to empower women with a migrant background to improve the integration process as project leader. 

The program of European Studies has allowed me to conduct an with the University of Malta. This was the place where both my interest in the Mediterranean region and the values for the EU came together. Consequently, I decided to write my bachelor's thesis on the adherence to the EUâ€™s Common Fundamental Values to protect the freedom of the press comparing Malta and Slovakia. 
After returning to The Hague, I decided to conduct my internship in Cyprus. The internship for DOREA Educational Institute allowed me to thoroughly analyze European policy together with the dynamics and needs of the European population. Based on this analysis I participated in developing training courses for DOREA. I am especially proud of the launch of the training course: â€œeducation for sustainable developmentâ€ that I have developed from the early stages.

After graduating from The Hague University of Applied Sciences, I have decided to further develop my knowledge on the Mediterranean region starting the Masterâ€™s program of European Union and Human Rights Studies at the Catholic University of Murcia. The program connected me with peers from all continents discussing contemporary issues with highly skilled lecturers such as ambassador Javier Vallaure, Bichara Khader and director of Social Economy Europe, VÃ­ctor Meseguer. I have conducted an internship with Social Economy Europe where I have gained insight into the social economy and advocacy, as well as social media content creation and monitoring. Finally, I have utilized my passion for Europe by writing my final masterâ€™s thesis on the importance of European identity building by virtue of my participation in the Erasmus program.

summary:
I am a mathematician and a computer scientist.  My research interests include: 

- AI-based applications of Interactive theorem prover Lean, and development of Lean-based ML tools 
- Application of formal methods in category theory to distributed systems. 
- Application of formal methods to the block chain technology and the connection between of verification system to the block chains and smart contracts.


I did my undergraduate in mathematics in Iran and my masters in mathematics at the University of Western Ontario, in Canada. After finishing my masters, in pursuit of my interests in functional programming languages, type theory, and proof verification systems I moved to UK to join the Theory of Computation group at the University of Birmingham. 

At Birmingham, I have been a researcher and also a demonstrator for a variety of modules including Functional programming languages (Haskell and OCaml), Java workshop, and Models Of Computation for three years. 

I am also an avid reader of history and philosophy.

name: Ioannis Diamantis
skills: ['Knot theory', 'Geometric topology', 'Abstract Algebra', 'Combinatorics', 'R (Programming Language)', 'Advanced Mathematics', 'Topology', 'Python (Programming Language)', 'Complex analysis', 'Advanced trigonometry', 'Group Theory', 'Pre-Calculus', 'Vector Calculus', 'AP Calculus', 'Multivariate Statistics', 'Business Statistics', 'Mathematical Statistics', 'Engineering Statistics', 'Nonparametric Statistics', 'College algebra']
summary:
I am a geometric-topologist and my primary area of research is knot theory, braid groups and 3-manifolds. My research focuses on the construction of Jones-type invariants for knots and links in 3-manifolds other than the 3-sphere (skein modules), using knot algebras and Markov traces. Recently, I developed an interest on tied links, on pseudo knots, on knotoids & on weaves/tilings.

Highlights:

1. Teaching Award 2018-2019, China Agricultural University

2. Teaching Award 2017-2018, China Agricultural University

3. Awards for Research 2017 & 2020, China Agricultural University 

4. Research Visits:
i. @ Harbin Engineering University, Dec. 2016 (Campus Visit & talk on Skein Modules) 
ii. @ MF Oberwolfach, Germany, April 2015 (Research In Pairs with S. Lambropoulou and B. Gabrovsek)
iii. @ Derby university, UK, February 2020 (Campus visit and talk on Engineering Mathematics).
iv. @ Leiden University, The Netherlands, March & April 2023.

5. Local organizer of the International Conference on Knots, Low-dimensional topology and applications: Knots in Hellas 2016, International Olympic Academy,  Ancient Olympia, Greece, 16-22 July 2016.

6. Organizer of a 9-week seminar on Low-dimensional topology & Knot theory at China Agricultural University, College of Science, Sept.-Oct. 2019.

Since February 1 of 2019, I have been working as a software developer at the company 12Care, the creator of https://careweb.nl.

In 2015 I completed the bachelor's degree programme Mathematics at the Vrije
Universiteit Amsterdam. This study comprised of math topics like algebra,
analysis, probability theory, statistics and topology, and other useful skills
like computer programming (Java and C++), giving presentations and scientific
writing.

At the end of my bachelor's I learned how one can use Vim digraphs and the
XeLaTeX package unicode-math to add math symbols to documents in a more
convenient way. For instance, to add the symbol Î², one normally has to type
"\beta", but with this method one only has to enter "b<backspace>*" which
results in the typing of Î² directly in the .tex document. Then, the package
unicode-math makes sure this unicode character Î² is handled correctly by
XeLaTeX.  I think every mathematician should try this method.

After my bachelor's, I started the master's Mathematics, also at the Vrije
Universiteit Amsterdam. I abandoned this study in May 2017 to look for a job
as a computer programmer. 

A few interests of mine are single-board ARM computers and the Chinese language. My math is fine,

summary:
Ph.D. in arithmetic geometry, more precisely applications and properties of curves of low genus over finite fields, their jacobians and kummer surfaces for primality testing. Moreover alternative proofs on the bound of the cardinality of algebraic curves over finite fields. These topics oriented to the theory of cryptography.

Experience with steganographic and cryptographic algorithms/protocols design and programming.

I mainly work with C/python language in UNIX environments.

My publications in the academia are more related to arithmetic on jacobians of genus 2 curves and the Riemann Hypothesis of genus 2 curves on characteristic p. Also primality testing using Kummer surfaces and different proofs of the Hasse Weil Inequality.

On programming I have experience with evolution and genetic algorithms, steganography with JPEG images, Linux Kernel, sockets, Posix threads, IPC and scientific libraries like openssl, GMP, GSL, PARI, SAGE, MAGMA. I have experience with OpenGL and computational geometry in non euclidean spaces. Also I have experience with telecomm secure protocol design (client/server), compression and GPS, low level implementation of cryptographic protocols, captcha design.

I am not fan but I have a lot of experience with opensource databases on UNIX, sever administration for HTTP, SMTP, DB services, and web programming, server security, automated monitoring, virtualization and auditing in my prior job at a big IT company in Mexico.

I have given some international conferences related to cryptography, algebraic geometry, number theory and steganography mainly, I hold a master degree in pure mathematics focused in commutative algebra and a Ph.D. in algebra/arithmetic geometry.

I am kind of an expert in SPARK (Python+Databricks), Splunk and just got the certifications

Databricks Python Spark developer
GCFA  (GIAC Forensic Analyst)
GREM (GIAC Revese engineering)

My main research topics include logic, algebra, topology and category theory, as well as the connections between these topics.

I also have some experience in programming. Throughout my education, I mastered languages such as Python, C, Java and Haskell and acquired skills such as object-oriented programming, functional programming and formal verification (using proof assistants).
My theoretical computer science knowledge ranges over lambda calculus, various type theories, automata theory and complexity theory.

For a survey of my writing samples, please have a look at my personal webpage. For an overview of my programming projects, you can consult my GitHub profile.

Jan de Lange is mathematician by education. (Leiden. Detroit, Utrecht). After teaching at high schools and universities he became educational reseacher at the Freudenthal Institute for Innovation in Mathematics Education (University Utrecht). Shortly thereafter het became leader and full professor/director of this institute. He initiated many new projects and activities like the Nieuwe Wiskrant (Math Magazine), National Mathematics Days, Math-A-lympiade, designed learning materials (Math-in-Context), designed curricula (mathematics A). At present he is senior designer of  a tablet based curriculum for mathematics for Pearson in the USA. 
He also was member or chair of many national and international commissions (Mathematical Sciences Education Board (Washington DC), Chair of International Expert Group PISA Mathematics (Paris, Melbourne), Visiting Professor University of Wisconsin (Madison), Honorary Chair Mathematics Education Research Institute (Being).

He founded the Project Curious MInds with Robbert Dijkgraaf & Johan van Benthem in 2005, and as a result the Book "Play Smart" was published in Dutch in 2013. It is about the amazing talents of young children, their curiosity, their reasoning skills, especially in the area of science and technology. It offers parents tools to facilitate a more complete cognitive development.This book is also the backbone of the recently started Young Parents Academy (jongeouderacademie.nl).
 
In 2011 he won the Lifetime Achievement Award van de International Society for Design and Development in Education (ISDDE).

He has presented numerous keynotes and lectures in 60 countries over a wide variety of subjects.

summary:
I am an applied Mathematician. I completed my PhD in 2018  at The University of Auckland in New Zealand. After that, I moved to Chile and took a one-year research break in which I was mostly dedicated to teaching, my newborn daughter and to apply for research grants. Between 2019 and 2020 I conducted research  at Universidad TÃ©cnica Federico Santa MarÃ­a in Chile, funded by the Agencia Nacional de InvestigaciÃ³n y Desarrollo (ANID), and since 2021 I am a research associate at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, funded by a EPSRC grant on Higher-order interactions and heteroclinic network dynamics.

My research so far lies primarily on the field of dynamical systems and its applications. I like to apply a combination of both analytical and computational tools to understand dynamical phenomena in different contexts. I am motivated by application-driven problems in which you can use math to understand and explain what's going on in real-life contexts. I have always learnt new computational skills on the go as needs arise and always looking for new skills to put in my toolbox. I'm eager to expand the scope of my research, as I'm willing to learn new techniques and methods.  I like to work in an encouraging and challenging environment and team up with motivated people.

summary:
Remco Tuinier is Full Professor of Physical Chemistry at Eindhoven University of Technology, the Netherlands. He studied food science at Wageningen University and performed his PhD work at the NIZO food research institute and Wageningen University on exocellular polysaccharides and protein-polysaccharide mixtures, for which he received the International Food Ingredient Award in 1999. Subsequently, he worked as Postdoctoral fellow at Utrecht University and as Project Leader at NIZO food research and in 2001 became a staff member at the Forschungszentrum JÃ¼lich, Germany. Between 2008 and 2015 he worked at DSM ChemTech Center, Advanced Chemical Engineering Solutions, Geleen, the Netherlands. First as Senior and later as Principal Scientist. He combined this with a part-time position at Utrecht University (UU) at the Van 't Hoff laboratory for Physical and Colloid Chemistry. With Henk N.W. Lekkerkerker he wrote the book 'Colloid and the Depletion Interaction' (Springer), which appeared in 2011. Between 2013 and 2020 he held the part-time chair 'Colloid-Polymer Mixtures' at UU. Since 2015 he is full professor of Physical Chemistry at Eindhoven University of Technology and is heading the Laboratory of Physical Chemistry within the Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry. Remco Tuinier is a member of the Institute of Complex Molecular Systems (ICMS). Remco is member of the Editorial Advisory Board of The Journal of Chemical Physics, and member of the COSI foundation board. Further he chairs the board of the Overbeek foundation.

Scientific interests:
Polymers and colloids at surfaces
Depletion forces and phase behaviour
Self- and co-assembly of (block-co)polymers and surfactants
Self-consistent field theory
Complexation of charged macromolecules and colloidal particles
Colloid dynamics (diffusion and sedimentation) through polymer solutions and concentrated dispersions
Light-, X-Ray and Neutron Scattering
Macro- and microrheology

summary:
I develop chemical theories and methods for rationally designing molecules, nano-structures and materials as well as chemical processes toward these compounds, based on quantum mechanics and computer simulations. An essential part of these efforts is the application of our theories and models in cooperation with experimental groups. The project comprises four main directions of research that are intimately connected and reinforce each other: (1) Structure and Chemical Bonding in Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory (DFT), (2) Supramolecular Chemistry and Theoretical Biochemistry, (3) Elementary Chemical Reactions [see: Activation Strain model; Pyfrag], and (4) Fragment-oriented Design of Catalysts.

Specialties: Molecular Structure, Chemical Bonding, Reactivity, Theoretical Biochemistry, Chemical Reactivity, Catalysis, Supramolecular Chemistry

name: Irene Groot
skills: ['Dynamics at Surfaces', 'Heterogeneous Catalysis', 'Ultrahigh vacuum', 'Surface Science', 'Molecular Astrophysics', 'Supersonic molecular beams', 'Density Functional Theory', 'Scanning Tunneling Microscopy', 'Low energy electron diffraction', 'Auger electron spectroscopy', 'Quasiclassical and quantum dynamics calculations', 'Gas Chromatography', 'Infrared spectroscopy', 'Molecular', 'Surface Chemistry', 'IR spectroscopy', 'Physical Chemistry', 'Chemistry', 'Surface', 'Spectroscopy']
summary:
My scientific career focuses on the study of heterogeneously catalyzed processes on the atomic scale using surface science techniques and density functional theory. I am interested in the fundamental aspects that govern physical and chemical processes taking place at the surfaces of nano-sized materials.
I study different chemical reactions that are enabled or enhanced by the use of catalysts. Examples of these chemical reactions are H2 dissociation, CO oxidation and chlorine production. Using a combination of surface science techniques under ultrahigh vacuum conditions and in situ operando methods I follow the changes of catalytic surfaces before, during and after reaction, while at the same time measuring the reactants and products. This combination enables me to link surface morphology to catalytic reactivity.
When more fundamental insights in these processes are gained, better catalysts can be developed, thereby saving energy, resources and money.

My studies in MSc Analytical Science for Industry at King's College London encouraged my interest in the field. I was instructed about the most modern analytical techniques applied in the industry and laboratories worldwide. Among advanced analytical techniques such as GC-MS and HPLC-MS, including all different types of mass analyzer and modes of ionization in mass spectrometry, I was also taught about emerging technologies, such as point of care testing, supercritical fluid chromatography, ICP-MS, orbitrap, lab-on-a-chip and micro-fluidics, evaporative light scattering detection, as well as immunoassay, ion pairing chromatography and electrophoresis. I am passionate about Chemistry and thoroughly enjoy teaching it. My students, both in school and in one-to-one sessions, are of various abilities and as such I have developed methods that aim to stretch the more able, as well as support less able students through scaffolding to achieve their full potential. 

I know that every student has a different way of learning and therefore adapt my lessons accordingly and have a wealth of resources for all levels. summary:
Ewald Edink obtained a bachelor degree in organic chemistry at the Higher Laboratory Education in Rotterdam in 2000. After working at the Technical University in Delft and DSM as a research technician, he completed the master education Pharmacochemistry (Drug Design and Synthesis track) at the VU University in Amsterdam in 2006. 

In his PhD project at the VU University, he focused on the structure-based design of ligands for acetylcholine-binding protein, a structural homolog of the ligand-binding domain of Cys-loop receptors. After completion of his PhD, Ewald continued at the VU University as a postdoctoral researcher on a EU-project that focused on the development of therapeutics against human influenza.

In 2012, he joined Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) as a Medical Affairs Officer Psychiatry and returned in November 2013 to the medicinal chemistry department of the VU University in Amsterdam where he became project leader for the PDE4NPD project in which parasitic phospodiesterases are targeted with small molecule inhibitors to find novel treatments for neglected parasitic diseases (www.pde4npd.eu). In 2016, Ewald became lecturer at Hogeschool InHolland where he is involved in teaching chemistry to undergraduate students and has a keen interest in all aspects of (ICT-supported) Blended Learning.

name: Zeila Zanolli
position 1: Associate Professor, Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Science and Chemistry Department
position 2: Expert Evaluator for the EC H2020 FET OPEN RIA program
skills: ['Nanomaterials', 'Physics', 'Nanotechnology', 'Materials Science', 'Solid State Physics', 'Scientific Computing', 'Science', 'Theory', 'Scientific Research', 'Nanomaterial modeling', 'Computer simulation', 'DFT', 'magnetism', 'quantum electron transport', 'Molecular Dynamics', 'Mathematical Modeling', 'Computational Physics', 'Carbon Nanotubes', 'Nanoparticles', 'graphene']
summary:
I work on the modeling of the structural, electronic, magnetic and quantum electron transport properties of nanomaterials using first-principles computational techniques as Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Non-Equilibrium Greenâ€™s Function (NEGF). 
The results of my research activity have been published in journals of high impact factor (IF) as Nano Letters, ACSnano, Phys Rev Lett... 
The investigated systems range from Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs), monatomic C chains, BN nanoribbons, III-V semiconductor nanowires, multiferroic materials. 
These investigations have lead to a deep understanding of the fundamental physical properties of one-dimensional systems that, in turn, is essential to design new nanoelectronic and spintronic devices and/or improve their performances. For this reason, these works are often conducted in direct collaboration with experimentalists.
For instance, I have investigated a number of functionalization schemes of CNTs in order to achieve selective detection of various gas molecules. I have employed NEGF and DFT to predict spin-polarized electron transport in monatomic C chains connected to graphene nanoribbons, hence simulating the behavior of all-C nanoelectronic devices. 
I have experience also in using beyond-DFT techniques as the GW approximation. I have used GW to compute the band-gap of the wurtzite polymorph of InAs and GaAs in order to explain photoluminescence measurements (performed by myself) on III-V NWs. Recently, I've performed further modelling of III-V NWs to identify the optimal conditions to grow straight InAsâ€“onâ€“GaAs NW heterostructures. Presently, I'm modelling magnetic multiferroic superlattices, aiming at applications as spintronic devices and, in particular, magnetically readable and electrically writable random access memories (M-RAM).

Specialties: ab initio calculations, nanoscale device modelling, nanoelectronic, spintronic, electrical and optical characterication at the nano- and micro-scale, clean room fabrication.

The focus of the research programme of my laboratory is to develop and apply new Physical microscopy methods at the interface with Chemistry and Biology to shed light on the biomolecular processes underlying cell function, ageing and neurodegeneration. I undertake a similar approach to study advanced functional surfaces and materials.

To pursue these objectives, I continuously push the boundaries and capabilities of methods of analysis of modern physics and chemistry in which I have deep expertise, such as nanoscale microscopy and spectroscopy, surface science, artificial intelligence and image processing.

I hold a PhD in Biophysics obtained at the Ã‰cole Polytechnique FÃ©dÃ©rale de Lausanne (EPFL) in Switzerland, where I acquired a strong expertise on scanning probe microscopy and single molecule methods.

During my previous research experience at the EPFL and Cambridge University, I have acquired strong expertise in research design, communication and management of scientific teams and large international collaborations.

I work alongside several undergraduate and graduate students as a mentor and supervisor. In my mentoring, I focus at developing the independence of the students to approach a problem of interest for the scientific community and society. 

For a complete list of publications please see:

https://research.wur.nl/en/persons/francesco-s-ruggeri

summary: Professor of Physical Chemistry of Soft Matter at the Radboud University in Nijmegen (NL), heading an experimental soft condensed matter group with particular expertise in colloid chemistry and physics, video and confocal microscopy, optical tweezing and image analysis. summary:
As a teacher I have to be able to explain things clearly and positively, both verbally and in writing. Good communication skills are some of the simplest, most essential tools for teaching. 
Open hands, good eye contact, smiling, good posture, respect for othersâ€™ personal space: these are all part of good communication. Having good body language establishes trust and means students will not only have more confidence in you, but will want to listen to and work with you. 
By using three languages confidently, I become better at observing my surroundings and adept at focusing on relevant information and editing out the irrelevant. I tend to make more rational decisions. Because any language contains nuance and subtle implications in its vocabulary, and these biases can subconsciously influence my judgment. Good language means that my diction is clear and audible, my sentences are concise, my thought processes are logical and my delivery is flowing.

A natural sceintist loves to explain things. The ability to explain things clearly and effectively can help the scientist to become a good teacher. This teacher is like a candle - it consumes itself to light the way for others but passing on knowledge, interests and challenges to the next generation of undergraduates is a rewarding outcome.

peptide/protein discovery and development scientist. 

Iâ€™m research scientist working to develop technologies that benefit human health. My main area of interest is discovery and development of pharmaceutical drug entities. I have more than 6 years of post-Ph.D. experience in peptide therapeutics, medicinal chemistry and protein/antibody. My key strength is phage display screening, lead generation and optimization, project management and have experience working with modalities like small molecule, peptide, macrocycle, protein and antibody. I have very good knowledge and skills in peptide chemistry, medicinal chemistry, peptide and antibody phage display, high-throughput screening, pharmacokinetics, molecular biology, biological assays, bioanalytical and biophysical tools.

A little about meâ€¦

Originally from India, now reside in Amsterdam area and continue to serve global clients for peptide/protein/antibody discovery and development project. One of main role is to expand exiting peptide-phage discovery technology and managing internal and external projects. I am very much looking forward to working on challenging projects.

Prior to that as a scientific staff, I have contributed in establishing protein-peptide phage display technology on safe drugs for pain and inflammation using phage display at Max Planck Institute for Medical Research. 

During my postdoctoral tenure at EPFL, I have managed various projects and developed two-platform technology for early drug discovery based on double bridge peptide-phage display and traceless high-throughput screening of macrocycles. I have also performed antibody phage display against Tacrolimus to develop point-of-care diagnostic applications and selective bioconjugation of antibody.

I am a chemist by training, did my Ph.D. in chemistry. I have contributed in the field of on peptide, bioorganic and medicinal chemistry. I have designed, synthesized and studied novel peptide foldamers and performed multistep organic synthesis of peptidomimetics and natural products.

summary:
I grew up in Downey, California. After graduating from Downey High School, I attended the California State University of Long Beach (CSULB) where I was a Presidential Scholar. While at CSULB, I majored in chemistry and minored in mathematics. I performed research in organic chemistry with Dr. Kensaku Nakayama and in physical chemistry with Dr. Brian McClain. After graduating from CSULB (summa cum laude) in 2007 I attended graduate school at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).

At UCLA, I joined the group of Dr. Benjamin Schwartz where I investigated the structural properties of the hydrated electron using mixed quantum/classical molecular dynamics simulations. While at UCLA I also acted as a teaching assistant for many quarters, eventually earning the Hanson-Dow Excellence in Teaching Award in 2009. I participated in the NSF GK-12 program where I acted as a resident scientist for local high schools from 2010-2011. I completed my dissertation in 2014.

After obtaining my Ph.D., I was hired as a visiting-assistant professor at Sonoma State University from 2014-2015. There I worked on developing a Foundational Level General Science Waiver. In 2015 I lectured at Loyola Marymount University and participated in the Center for Teaching Excellence Credential Program.

I am an Associate Adjunct Professor at UCLA, where I teach general and organic chemistry. My work at UCLA also includes chemical education research conducted under the advisement of Dr. Arlene Russell. One of the major projects is focused on the development and implementation of general chemistry courses designed to increase retention amongst students at risk of leaving the STEM field. Another project includes investigating specific interventions in the laboratory in order to increase student accuracy and precision with glassware.

My husband was offered work in the Netherlands, so I am currently on leave from UCLA. My hope is that I can use the next few years to further develop my skills as an educator and researcher.

PhD candidate in the group of Molecular Materials and Nanosystems, at the Eindhoven University of Technology.

My goal is to develop new materials for sustainable energy applications. I want to contribute to scientific breakthroughs and see my research transformed into commercial products.

My field is functional thin film materials science: find relations between growth, (defect)structure and  physical properties in relation to their application.

At present we aim for applications based on metal hydrides, such as hydrogen sensors. In addition, we explore the properties of oxyhydride thin films in relation to photochromism and hydride ion conduction.

summary:
Chief Executive Officer & co-founder of MolKet (under construction), a superposition of tech and service startup. An AI-assistant which helps in writing chemistry packages and modules for molecular design in chemistry and materials and choose the best computing architecture to  perform large scale computations. Choices include quantum computers, high performance computing, and special dedicated chips like GPUs, TPUs, and ASIC AI. 
 MolKet offers designing new smart solutions leveraging quantum technologies and quantum chemistry. 

PhD candidate in quantum theoretical and computational chemistry at Radboud University Nijmegen, the Netherlands. 

Selim holds a master degree in physics, lasers, and materials from University of Burgundy and University of Paris-Saclay from France. 

===
 MolKet: Co-founded with Alain ChancÃ©, the Chief Business Officer and co-founder. MolKet offers an integrated cloud services with modular design tools that enable customers to perform molecular design and computations in a modular fashion without worrying about the efficiency or the coding parts of the core modules for the simulations. MolKet optimizer, based on the problem, can choose the proper computing architecture for the problem.In that way, the user can harness the power of the hybrid architecture combining quantum computing with high performance computing. Choices include QPUs, GPUs, CPUs, and special computing chips like ASIC AI and TPUs. Among the services, training, consultancy, and knowledge transfer are presented as well.  

PhD publications: co-authored few profound publications involving new quantum computational methods and algorithms to enable large molecular simulations in computational chemistry for the multi-billion international James Webb Space Telescope within the Dutch Astronomical Network II. Such methods and algorithms are integrated in the simulation packages to provide data used by researchers studying the chemical anatomy of interstellar media such as protoplanetary disks in deep outer space. 

M.Sc. thesis: Simulating  the quantum control process and fine-tune the femtosecond laser parameters to control the reactions channels and favor the desired outcomes. The project presents the basis for chemical control for a personal care company. 

B.Sc.: contributed to test new types of super-symmetric Hamiltonians (SUSY-H). These Hamiltonian provide easy way to compute excited states using second quantization using the variational principle.

summary:
My name is Elise van Diejen, 26 years old, and I work as an Associate Scientist at Ardena. In 2016 I graduated with a Bachelors degree in Chemistry, major Analytical Chemistry, and I successfully completed the Analytical Science Talent Program. During my bachelor I worked on four different internships, where I gained experience with Ion Chromatography, Fourier Transform Infrared and UPLC-MS. After my graduation, I started working part time at the lectorate for innovative testing in Life Sciences and Chemistry at the Hogeschool Utrecht. Here, I worked on project-based activities using HPLC. In December 2016, I started working at Steris, where I worked for more than three years. I started there as a chemical analyst, where I performed chemical analysis on pharmaceutical products using HPLC-UV, among other techniques. After two years working as a chemical analyst I had the opportunity to develop myself as a technical analyst, where I was responsible for the analytical equipment in the lab. In February 2020 I started working at TMC and directly started with a project at the Wageningen University and Research. For half a year I was a chemical analyst and I gained experience with Ion Chromatography, HPSEC and working with different food and biomass samples. Since January 2021 I started at Ardena, so I am back in the pharmaceutical sciences. My work will consist of (HPLC) method development and optimization, validations and stability studies for various sorts of medicines.

I consider myself to be accurate, ambitious and environmentally friendly. Because of my enthusiasm I am capable of motivating myself as well as others, and I am a perfectionist. When it comes to work, I prefer quality over quantity. I am eager to learn and improve myself, by both deepening my knowledge in certain techniques as well as broadening my knowledge in a more general sense. I like to think out-of-the-box when it comes to problem solving. I prefer to work in an environmentally friendly setting where I have the opportunity to develop myself. For me it would be interesting to gain more experience with LC-MS as well as method development.

summary:
Chemical engineer with an interest for molecular systems with functional applications to make the world a more sustainable and enjoyable place.

As a PhD candidate and researcher at Eindhoven University of Technology, I focused on the development of autonomously responsive materials for functional devices based on liquid crystalline polymers. The combination of novel materials of that type with additive manufacturing was used to create â€œ4D printedâ€ devices, such as a beetle that changes colour when in contact with water, or a clamshell design that opens and shuts in response to atmospheric humidity. This research was made possible by a complete chain-of-knowledge approach from the organic synthesis used to make the functional monomers, to processing into the devices, and finally thorough characterisation and dissemination in the form of academic journal articles and at public events.

After graduating with the thesis â€œCholesteric Liquid Crystals in Additive Manufacturingâ€, I worked briefly for deep-tech university spin-off Lusoco on the development of luminescent inks for solar energy harvesting materials. Since October of 2022, I'm employed by TNO at Holst Centre, where my expertise in polymer and materials science is used in the research of 3D printed electronics.

name: Nico Sommerdijk
position 2: Full Professor Bio-inspired and Multiscale Materials
skills: ['Electron Microscopy', 'Biomineralization', 'Inspirational Leadership', 'Creative Problem Solving', 'Supportive mentoring ', 'Bridge Building ']
summary:
My research focusses on the mechanisms of mineralization in bone formation and in pathological calcification, where I use creative imaging approaches to study the structural and (bio)chemical aspects of these processes with the highest spatial and temporal resolution. 

Unraveling the molecular mechanisms of biological mineralization processes is of the greatest importance for the development of new therapeutic strategies that will help to shift treatments from surgical intervention to prevention, e.g. in the treatment of Calcifying Aortic Valve Disease. 

To study the biological processes as close as possible to the native conditions we emulate matrix formation and mineralization using human in vitro systems, including organoids and bone-on-a-chip devices. We monitor these processes with a variety of advanced microscopic and spectroscopic methods to cover all relevant length and time scales (www.mineralizedtissues.com). 

These advanced imaging strategies are developed within the Radboud Electron Microscopy Center, where we closely collaborate with many companies (Zeiss, CryoCapCell, Thermo Fischer/FEI, DENSsolutions, VitroTEM) to constantly improve our imaging capabilities and to push the boundaries of the science and eventually healthcare.

name: Fausto Gallucci
skills: ['Membranes', 'Reaction Engineering', 'multiphase reactors', 'chemical looping', 'separation technology', 'Process Engineering', 'Modeling', 'Separation', 'Research', 'Teaching', 'Membrane', 'Multiphase Flow', 'Chemical', 'Reactor', 'Catalysis', 'Chemistry', 'Materials Science', 'Organic Chemistry', 'Chemical Engineering', 'Thermodynamics']
summary:
Fausto Gallucci studied Chemical Engineering at the University of Calabria (UNICAL, Arcavacata di Rende, Italy) where he obtained his MSc (2001) and PhD (2006) degrees. He performed his PhD research on hydrogen production from methanol in membrane reactors. In 2007, after having held a position as a postdoctoral researcher at the Research Institute on Membrane Technology  (ITM-CNR, at the UNICAL campus), Gallucci moved to the research group Fundamentals of Chemical Reaction Engineering at the University of Twente (Enschede, The Netherlands). In 2009 he was appointed Assistant Professor (tenure track) there. The following year, Gallucci moved to the Chemical Process Intensification laboratory at Eindhoven University of Technology (TU/e, The Netherlands) where he was appointed Associate Professor in 2015, leading the Multiphase Reactors research effort. In 2018 he was appointed full Professor at the chair 'Inorganic Membranes and Membrane Reactors'

The research of Fausto Gallucci at the Inorganic Membranes and Membrane Reactors (SIR) research group is related to the development of membranes and novel multiphase reactors, in particular membrane reactors and dynamically operated reactors. His research focuses on the interaction of heterogeneous catalysis, transport phenomena, and fluid mechanics in these novel multifunctional reactors. Particularly interesting application areas are methanol production in zeolite and carbon membranes, methane activation with oxygen selective membranes, the Fischer-Tropsch reaction in carbon based membrane reactors, and hydrogen production by reforming/dehydrogenation reactions with hydrogen selective membranes, sorption enhanced and chemical looping reactors, plasma reactors. The novel reactor research is carried out through integration of (in house developed) advanced experimental techniques and experimental Proof of Concept of novel reactor concepts. The SIR chair coordinates and participates in several large European Projects and works in strict collaborations with partners like TECNALIA, POLIMI, UManchester, Unsa, Engie, KT, ICI, JM and others.

name: Rob Liskamp
position 1: Guest Professor of Molecular Medicinal Chemistry
position 2: Honorary Senior Research Fellow, Formerly Professor of Chemical Biology and Medicinal Chemistry
skills: ['Research', 'Teaching', 'Higher Education', 'Science', 'Public Speaking', 'University Teaching', 'Lecturing']
summary:
Rob Liskamp studied Chemistry at the University of Nijmegen, The Netherlands and obtained his Ph.D. in Bio-organic Chemistry in 1982 (cum laude). Post-doctoral research (1983-1986) was carried out in The Institute of Cancer Research and Department of Chemistry of Columbia University, New York. From 1986-1993 he was an assistant professor at the University of Leiden. In 1991 he was a visiting professor at the University of California in Los Angeles. In 1994 he became associate professor at Utrecht University and in 1996 professor of Molecular Medicinal Chemistry. In 2012, he was a visiting professor at the Universities of Leeds and Glasgow. In 2013 he was appointed Professor and Chair of Chemical Biology and Medicinal Chemistry at the University of Glasgow he has set up a new award-winning (2015) lab there, while maintaining a guest appointment as professor at the University of Utrecht. Recently he moved back to The Netherlands and became closely involved with Cristal Therapeutics in Maastricht as well as Maastricht University. Research interests included (enzymatic) synthesis of biologically active modified peptides and peptidomimetics, dendrimers, peptide folding, protein mimics including synthetic antibodies and vaccines.
He has > 300 publications; 7 reviews, 11 patents/applications; >14,000 citations and an h-index of 58.

www.gla.ac.uk/schools/chemistry/staff/robertliskamp/
http://www.liskamp-group.org

summary:
I have recently started as a PhD candidate at the soil chemistry & chemical soil quality group at Wageningen University & research. For my PhD research I am investigating how active treatment (i.e. flushing and aerating) of waste within landfills could reduce the contaminant release of the waste. If reduced in a sufficient amount, this could mean other more costly measures for prevent environmental contamination are no longer needed.

Before starting as a PhD student, I followed the master programme "Earth & Environment", during which I specialised in the biology and chemistry of soil and water with a specific focus on soil chemistry. For this programme, I wrote a master thesis about the calcium chloride extraction, and how varying factors within this extraction affected measured concentration of zinc, copper, and dissolved organic matter. Furthermore, I interned at NMI agro, during which I created a simple model capable of predicting nutrient leaching towards surface waters on a field scale.

summary: My Chair aims to understand protein damage  in the cell and their consequence for the origin of fatal diseases, such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's or Huntington's Disease. We aim to exploit our knowledge of the protein quality control machinery of the cell to develop new strategies targeting these diseases. Key questions are: Why does our defence fail when we get older? Why do some individuals get a protein-damage related disease and others do not? Can we boost the cellular defense system to prevent the origin of the disease, or at least prevent progress of the diseases for some cases? Can we develop drugs that specifically recognise the fatal, damaged protein and target them for removal?

summary: Kyra Defourny is a post doctoral scientist specialized in the study of extracellular vesicles (EVs). In her academic work, Kyra aims to address fundamental research questions regarding the release and function of EVs during infection, inflammation, and/or cell stress. Recently Kyra finished her PhD on the release of EV-enclosed picornaviruses, focusing on the virus-host interactions promoting the uptake of virus particles into EVs. By looking at virus infection, we can learn more about the regulation of EV release and the properties of EVs. Vice versa, knowledge on EVs is crucial to understand the properties of EV-enclosed viruses as long overlooked infectious agents during infection. Following up on her work Kyra is currently doing a post doc on the impact of virus infection on EV fusion efficiency, using novel microscopy-based reporter assays.

name: Frederic Lens
skills: ['Woodiness', 'Plants', 'Drought stress']
summary:
I obtained my PhD at KU Leuven (Belgium) in 2005, after which I have spent five years as a postdoc funded by the Flemish Science Foundation. In 2010, I was appointed as assistant professor (tenure tracker) at Leiden University, and moved to Naturalis Biodiversity Center (Leiden, The Netherlands) as permanent researcher in 2014, where I was promoted as senior researcher in 2018 and group leader in 2020. I was a visiting postdoc at Leiden University in 2006, at the University of Utah (USA) in 2009, and visiting professor at the University of Bordeaux (France) in 2013 and 2014.

During my PhD period as teaching assistant (2000-2005), I studied evolutionary and ecological signals in the wood anatomy of flowering plants. My postdoc internship in the Sperry lab (Univ. of Utah, USA) taught me how to perform water flow measurements in stems, which enabled me to functionally interpret wood anatomical observations with respect to different levels of drought stress resistance between species, with particular emphasis on the ultrastructure of intervessel pits. The outcome of this anatomical-hydraulic work has resulted in an award-winning paper on maples in New Phytologist (Tansley Medal for Excellence in Plant Science in 2010). Another line of research that has always fascinated me as an evolutionary biologist is to understand the frequent life form transitions in flowering plants, especially the growth form transition from herbaceousness towards (derived) woodiness. I just finished a unique global dataset on derived woodiness in flowering plants, showing that derived woodiness has evolved at least 600 times independently, which raises the intriguing question which (a)biotic factors triggered wood formation in all these lineages. Most of these derived woody species are native to dry continental vegetation types, which may point to palaeoclimatic drought periods as potential drivers behind wood formation in various herbaceous groups. 

In addition to the question why plants became woody during evolutionary history, I am interested to know what are the genes that have turned on the wood pathway in all these hundreds of derived woody groups using gene expression and QTL experiments in Arabidopsis and relatives. I hope my research could contribute to complementary directions, such as inducing woody and thus more drought resistant and taller phenotypes in otherwise herbaceous crops that may help us to produce more food in a world where plant growth will become more demanding due to climate change.

summary:
SMATI Hadjer is a marine sciences and coastal planning engineer, specializing in marine biology and marine ecology with a focus on marine biotechnology. Currently, she is pursuing a master's degree in applied economics at the European Institute of Marine Studies and the Agrocampus Institute in Brittany, with a specialization in the sea, environment, and agriculture.

Marine Biotechnology is a field gaining significant importance, combining various biotechnologies (white, green, red, and blue) with synthetic biology to create sustainable management solutions for genetic resources and food production. By integrating cutting-edge technologies with marine resources, it aims to develop valuable goods and services.

Hadjer's decision to pursue both marine biotechnology and applied economics was motivated by several factors. Firstly, the economic challenges posed by marine biotechnology and agricultural revolutions worldwide, in both northern and southern regions, require a comprehensive understanding of their impact and potential contributions to sustainable development. Secondly, her dual training allows her to analyze the broader implications of blue biotechnologies. 

Hadjer's primary interests encompass:

1) Algae Valorization: focusing on the extraction and utilization of bioactive compounds, including pigments, lipids, proteins and amino acids, polysaccharides, bioactive peptides, antimicrobial compounds, and biofertilizers. Fascinated by the characterization of polymers derived from algae. this approach contributes significantly to the development of a sustainable bio-based economy.

2) Marine Bioprospecting: aims to explore the marine environment to identify novel genetic resources with commercial potential. Can lead to discoveries of new drugs, enzymes, and functional ingredients for various industries.

3) Fisheries Management: regulating and conserving fish populations to ensure their long-term viability and maintain ecological balance within marine ecosystems.

These areas of interest serve as the foundation for Hadjer's potential research tasks, reflecting her personal motivation and dedication to advancing marine biotechnology and sustainable utilization of marine resources.

I have been interested in genetics and biology since secondary school and studied biomedical sciences at Oxford Brookes and biology at Liverpool John Moores for my undergraduate degree. It is during these years I became interested in working in bioinformatics and moved to Amsterdam and completed the bioinformatics and systems biology master course at the VU and UvA. 

I currently live in Groningen and work as a PhD student in the genetics department at the UMCG. My research focus is on linking genetic variation to phenotypic outcomes through gene expression using eQTL analysis in single-cell data. With this goal I work with the single-cell eQTL consortium which has created a pipeline to allow groups to easily collaborate and contribute to a meta-analysis method with high power to discover many cell type specific eQTLs.

summary:
I am a scientific entrepreneur striving for social impact. 

As a creative mind with a passion for science and innovation, I am committed to utilising my skills and knowledge to bring science and innovation to people. 

At OASYS NOW, we empower people to take control over their health data and contribute it to science securely. My work at OASYS NOW enables me to bring cutting edge technology and scientific advancements to society. We build technologies enabling secure DNA data exchange, that helps bring new treatments to patients faster.

My research at Erasmus Medical Center revolves around Genomic Privacy, meaning applying cryptographic techniques to the DNA data lifecycle (under supervision of Dr. Gennady Roshchupkin, Computational Population Biology Group in Department of Radiology and Department of Epidemiology).

My previous research, I conducted at the DNA Damage Repair Lab of Dr. Joris Pothof, Department of Molecular Genetics, Erasmus MC. I dove into how RNA sequencing data and Differential Expression measurements are created in Aging research in different tissues. I unraveled a novel bias by combining knowledge of the underlying mathematical assumptions in the algorithms, with how the biological processes of aging shape the gene expression data. I also built a pipeline to compensate for this sample specific gene length bias that uncovered many differentially expressed genes in aging that weren't detectable previously.

As a co-founder of Hologenomix Life Sciences, I am dedicated to decoding the microbial landscape within different microbiomes. Our mission is to pave the way for groundbreaking discoveries and innovative solutions in personalized medicine and environmental sustainability.
