Peter Kolarov is the Founder and CEO of Crayonic, a cybersecurity startup launched in 2015 focused on solving problems of proving the true identity of people and things in the digital domain.

Peter is an experienced entrepreneur and technologist who spent the past 15 years architecting, developing and selling award-winning electronic signature and IAM solutions to global customers in finance. He also speaks at different events and hackathons on topics of electronic signatures, self-sovereign identities, secure decentralized authentication and real-world blockchain applications.

Prior to the launch of Crayonic, Peter worked for Anasoft APR (2006-2015) as a senior Solution Architect focusing on the cybersecurity field of Identity and Access Management and digital signatures.

In 2003, he launched a mobile software development company and developed multiple projects such as an interactive TV platform and TV station that sold later to a Norwegian TV network.

He co-founded his first startup in 2000 (Strings Inc., Seattle, WA) around unique variable data printing and templating technology that he developed for PDF print-ready documents. He sold the company to EFI/Printcafe in 2001.

Prior to this, in 1994, he joined a startup video game development company in Redmond, WA, where he led the software development team creating multiple high-profile titles across different platforms such as the Harry Potter series.

Peter was born in former Czechoslovakia. He studied Electrical Engineering in Bratislava, Slovakia and at the University of Nevada, Reno and graduated at the top of his class.

Hello dear viewer! You stumbled upon that crazy student, who felt bored at the lectures and afterward always run to do some "board meeting", "project" or "event" instead of a beer.

Lately,  I co-founded the first club of psychologist at our university, where we delivered workshops and brought alumni and external speakers to give practical advices. 

However, most of my activity of my bachelor studies belonged to youth leadership organization AIESEC which feed my need for experiences the most. From very first year I become a board member at AIESEC university office and later became a trainer at country level in Slovakia. All this knowledge & experience I utilized to get to a full-time position of country head of HR at AIESEC in Nepal. There I supported intensive growth and re-shaping of the organization, that was still recovering after massive earthquakes that happened a year before.

Lastly, I had also great opportunity to work at HR department in Dell in Slovakia. I am very grateful for a chance to meet a lot of HR professionals from whom I learned a lot about how human resources operates in the international company. 

Though above experiences shaped who I am, I'm would more likely define myself by my 3 core values of: Constant Improvement, Education & Honesty and my personal mission to contribute to improvement & innovation in education sector. 

Additionally, my current hobbies include acting&public speaking, painting, movies, travelling (34 countries), mountain trekking & my baby siblings. 

I'm always looking for cooperation or idea where I can contribute my skills and experience.

Once asked by a friend of mine: "How would you describe yourself in an alphabetical way?"

So here is my A to G personality catalog:
Analytical | Boundless | Creative | Diligent | Enthusiastic | Flexible | Goal-oriented

Here is a brief explanation for it: 
- I possess good analytical skill, enjoy working with database with the ability to look at issues from a helicopter view. 
- I'm a type of person who perceives challenges as opportunities to grow and achieve great results.
- I love seeing the world around me from different perspectives with entrepreneurial mindset to turn dreams into great visions. 
- I'm a hardworking, enthusiastic and flexible person who can quickly adapt to unexpected changes happen in midway while pursuing the tasks without being discouraged to stop by continuously aiming at the goal to achieve.
- I'm passionate about giving advises to people in difficult situations as I believe that is the way I can learn from their experiences.

I have four years experience working as a Data Analyst supporting the operations accross Europe, and I'm now in transitioning to Data Science and Big Data Analytics. summary:
Jozef Varga was born in NovÃ© Zamky (Slovakia) on May 12th 1979. He graduated with honors from the
Dance Conservatory in Slovakia in 1997. During his studies he performed with the Slovakian National 
Ballet and the Prague International Ballet. He continued his studies at the AcadÃ©mie de Danse Princesse Grace in Monte Carlo with Marika Besobrasova who worked with unrivalled stars like Rudolf Nureyev and created generations of outstanding dancers. In 1999 he joined Zurich Ballet as demi-soloist and was promoted to principal dancer in 2002 at the young age of 23. Under the direction of Heinz Spoerli he danced many lead roles and took part in new creations. Wanting to expand his repertoire and looking for new challenges he joined the Dutch National Ballet as principal dancer in 2007. In 2009 he recorded a DVD of the ballet Giselle in the role of Count Albrecht in a new production of the Dutch National Ballet which received international acclaim. He regularly has guest appearances with numerous companies such as The Royal Swedish Ballet, Turkish National Ballet, and Kazan Ballet Theatre and took part in a large number of international gala performances. More recently he worked on new creations with internationally renowned choreographers such as Christopher Wheeldon, Hans van Manen and Alexei Ratmansky. 
Jozef has won awards at several international ballet competitions and received the Alexandra Radius 
Prize (for rising young dance talent) in 2009. 
In 2012 the magazine Dance Europe included Jozef in their top 100 international dancers.
In 2015 Jozef danced the first vignette in the dance film â€œVoices of Financeâ€ based on the best-selling 
book â€œSwimming with Sharks: My journey into the World of the Bankersâ€ by Joris Luyendijk.
In 2015 Jozef was nominated by the President of the Unesco International Dance Council to become a 
member.

After the realisation that I will not make it as a professional musician I decided to focus my creativity elsewhere (I keep telling myself that I was close though...). field of studies 2: B.A. Environmental and Sustainability Studies - Innovation and Entrepreneurship, B.A. German
skills: ['Teamwork', 'English', 'Research', 'Training', 'Social Media', 'Event Management', 'Event Planning', 'Public Relations', 'Marketing Strategy', 'Social Networking', 'Systems Thinking', 'Qualitative Research', 'German', 'Management']
summary:
At its core, island tourism sells beautiful scenery and pristine nature. So why does it always end up
destroying the local environment? From an early age, this self-destructive paradox has both frustrated
and fascinated me. So much so, that people even started calling me Island Girl. After years of research on this topic, I am confident that if done correctly, tourism can fuel the growth of environmental resources instead of degrading them. This is not an easy task and requires many different stakeholders cooperating across industries.

My passion for island sustainability made me very aware of how vulnerable coastal areas are to climate
change. In September 2017 the true urgency hit me. While working on a project on the island
of Dominica, I experienced Maria: a category 5 hurricane that turned the entire country to rubble in only a few hours. This was a wakeup call for me that despite the importance of research, the window for action that actually makes a difference is closing.

To help island nations become more resilient against catastrophes like the one I experienced, I look at the big picture, break it down, and identify steps that can be taken to achieve the long-term desired results. For this reason, I enjoy working on creative projects with businesses (e.g. hotels) and also at the destination-level on strategic direction. I am interested in many aspects of sustainability, but if I would have to name one main area where I want to make a difference, it would be protecting animals and their habitats â€“ but I believe that this goes hand in hand with creating long-term economic and social prosperity. 

My mission is support islands in protecting their environment in a way that makes both common and financial sense.

name: LucÃ­a Hernando AgÃ¼ero
skills: ['Electrical Engineering', 'Space Systems', 'Aerospace Engineering', 'Telecommunications', 'Satellite Systems Engineering', 'Earth Observation']
summary:
â€œA journey of thousands miles begins with a single stepâ€ said Lao Tzu (c.600 BC). 
I like to read this quote at the start of a very demanding week for it reminds me that we can reach the sky and beyond if we take small steps in an orderly manner.

My journey in the space community started a bit by good fortune back in 2000 from my home country, Spain. At the time, I was most interested in bio-engineering and had just returned from an Erasmus programme in Greece. An opportunity for a one-year secondment within a French space company aroused and my employer thought of me as a candidate.  After this position, I returned to Madrid, then left again for France which was followed by an experience in the UK. Now I am settled in the Netherlands.

Some of the most exciting moments of my career so far took place during the launch campaigns and LEOP. Finally, the rocket lifts off. On board are the satellites you and many others have been working on for years, but all I can think about are technical questions related to my field of expertise: are batteries sufficiently charged to support the initial activities, will solar arrays deploy as planned? Perfectionism is my weak pointâ€¦

I enjoy working in the multicultural work environment at the European Space Agency. I am native Spanish speaker fluent in two foreign languages both spoken with a Spanish accent. I am curious and like to learn new things or ways. I love to keep increasing my skills. I have recently completed a Master of Space System and Business Engineering from TU Graz University in Austria. After working for Telecom, Science and Earth Observation missions, through this Master, I discovered more about Space Exploration, and in particular Lunar Explorationâ€¦

As Neil Armstrong put it, this is one small step for manâ€¦

name: Florian Legters
skills: ['Commercials', 'Film', 'Dutch', 'Television', 'Feature Films', 'Video Production', 'Music Videos', 'Drama', 'Short Films']
summary:
Met de oprichting van ReadySet Studios is Nederland vanaf 1 maart een virtual production-studio rijker. De studio, gesitueerd in Amsterdam, stelt film- en televisiemakers in staat om op een groot LED-scherm iedere gewenste achtergrond of omgeving weer te geven. Met deze innovatieve manier van filmen kunnen traditionele filmsets virtueel worden uitgebreid, waarbij o.a. gebruik wordt gemaakt van de laatste technieken uit de game industrie.

In het kader van duurzaamheid is virtual production een welkome technologie die overal ter wereld in opkomst is, vaak met Disneyâ€™s recente productie The Mandalorian als lichtend voorbeeld. Met een hele film crew afreizen naar verre locaties kent nu een aantrekkelijk alternatief. Ook efficiÃ«ntie is een belangrijk pluspunt bij de toch al dure filmopnames, bijvoorbeeld doordat ongunstige weersomstandigheden met deze techniek vermeden worden. De coronapandemie heeft de ontwikkeling van virtual production in een stroomversnelling gebracht.

Het hoofdscherm van ReadySet Studios is 14 meter breed en 5,5 meter hoog met een groot LED-plafond en apart verrijdbaar scherm. De opstelling maakt gebruik van hoogwaardige display-technologie en is geÃ¯nstalleerd door het toonaangevende Nederlandse bedrijf Faber Audiovisuals. ReadySet Studios behoort in Europa direct tot de grootste in zijn soort en kan mede daardoor nu al rekenen op aandacht uit binnen- en buitenland.

skills: ['Multivariate data analysis', 'Applied statistics', 'Three-way data analysis', 'Multiway data analysis', 'Three-mode analysis', 'SPSS', 'Multivariate Analysis', 'Statistics', 'Statistical Modeling', 'Multivariate Statistics', 'Data Analysis', 'Science', 'Research', 'Lecturing', 'Teaching', 'Applied Mathematics', 'LaTeX', 'Quantitative Research', 'University Teaching', 'Dutch']
summary:
Pieter Marinus Kroonenberg is emeritus professor of Multivariate Analysis in particular of Three-Way Data. Until his retirement in 2014, he worked at the Faculty of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Leiden University, and is now director of The Three-Mode Company, a statistical consultancy agency. His main area of research is still three-mode and multiway data analysis and he is the author of a monograph on the subject and a suite of programs 3WayPack for such analyses; see the website of The Three-Mode Company. He has published papers on applications of multiway data analysis in a wide variety of disciplines. He is also interested in correspondence analysis, especially its application to three-way data. His book on Multivariate Humanities has now been published  by Springer.
https://rd.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-030-69150-9

locations. He is also experienced in working with third party suppliers, managed service contracts and outsourcing. He is also interested in areas next to oil and gas, like health care and education.

skills: ['Physics', 'Astronomy', 'Science', 'Research', 'Science Communication', 'Experimentation', 'Scientific Writing', 'LaTeX', 'Mathematics', 'Programming', 'University Teaching', 'Matlab', 'Python', 'Image Processing', 'Teaching', 'Organic Chemistry', 'Mathematica', 'Chemistry', 'Multivariate Statistics', 'Laser Physics']
summary:
I am an Australian radio astronomer based at ASTRON, where I am Head of the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) Science group. This position involves managing ~15 astronomers, and helping to form long-term science strategy for the institute. I am also an adjunct Assistant Professor at Leiden Observatory, Leiden University.

Scientifically, I specialise in studying stars and exoplanets at radio wavelengths, which provides information about how magnetic fields are generated on such bodies. Such information is important for helping assess whether certain planets have favourable conditions for life as we know it.

Previously, I was a Veni Fellow at Leiden University (2020-2023) and the de Bruyn postdoctoral fellowship at ASTRON (2017-2020). I completed my PhD in astrophysics at The University of Sydney in 2017. My PhD was focussed on understanding radio galaxy evolution and developing the Murchison Widefield Array (MWA), a SKA precursor.

summary:
In 2019, I completed a BSc in Cultural Anthropology and Development at the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands, during which I developed a great interest in gendered experiences of protracted conflicts, and in gender, religion, and popular culture in the Philippines. This latter interest gave way to ethnographic research in the Philippines with the following title: Fieldnotes on Love: unraveling how Philippine Love-Teams shape notions of romantic love.

In 2020, I obtained an MSc in Cultural Anthropology and Development Studies at the Radboud University in Nijmegen, for which I conducted ethnographic research on post-conflict social change through artistic storytelling promoted by community-based projects in Northern Ireland. Resulting in the following thesis: Narrating futures: an ethnographic take on artistic storytelling in the Theatre of Witness as a means to an end in Northern Ireland's quest for peace. 

After several research experiences in the Philippines and Northern Ireland, I now work as a junior researcher at the Radboud University, studying gender-based violence in post-conflict Northern Ireland. 

I also work as a volunteer at Jales, a non-profit developmental organization that is focused on offering financial support to provide educational opportunities for poor children in the Philippines. 

I aspire to bring about societal change where that is needed through research, education, and, or, work within a developmental organization. Through this work, I aim to contribute to knowledge about how we â€˜togetherâ€™ - as human beings - can envision and work towards a better future

summary:
I am a self-motivated and dedicated Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights enthusiast in Sierra Leone. 
I started a career in Healthcare as a volunteer in high school for the Nova Scotia Peer Health Education program in Sierra Leone in 2008. I engaged in multiple advocacies and behavioral change interventions at the local level. Also involved in climate change mitigation activities as a Green Scenery Club member in high school. 
I participated in environmental protection and sanitation throughout medical school. I contributed to implementing the Supplementary Immunization Activities projects at the university as a national supervisor and technical advisor. I worked in 60% of the district health management teams in Sierra Leone. I supported the DHMTs at the national and district teams and mentored staff in each domain of the project. 
I have worked in the four clinical disciplines as an intern for two years. 
Over the past four years, I have supported the country's Healthcare delivery teams at the upper, middle, and intervention levels in Sierra Leone. Recently,  I helped a team at Princess Christian Maternity Hospital, the largest maternity center in Sierra Leone, and focused on attending equitably to all walk-in obstetrics and gynecology clients with the best outcomes in mind.

Furthermore, I am experienced in healthcare delivery in the Mining sector. I worked with the Sierra Rutile mining company as a Medical Officer. I led the reproductive, maternal, and child health units in the health and safety context of best-practice in health delivery in the mining sector. 

As the District Medical Superintendent at Magburaka Government Hospital, I led a team of 300 clinical and other technical staff to provide Healthcare to over 500,000 people.  
Additionally, I am involved in advocacies linked to SDGs. Recently, I committed to Act Against Hospital hunger by raising funds to provide, at our hospital, food for pregnant women, lactating mothers, and children who seek Healthcare in the most deprived areas in Sierra Leone. Ensuring Zero Hunger, Improve Health, and Well-being are all relevant to achieving SDGs (2 &3). Please see what we do at https://facedonate.org/drtejan. 
I am managing the Port Loko Regional hospital and leading a team of over 400 staff, and working with partners to ensure to serve over 1 million people in the North Western  Sierra Leone.

I stand for equity, honesty, dedication, and hard work.
I am an early career public health professional, transitioning clinician, and looking forward to a more challenging job in Sierra Leone and Africa.

name: Dee Brillenburg Wurth

skills: ['Peacebuilding', 'Negotiation', 'Government', 'Conflict', 'Capacity Building', 'Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)', 'International Development', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights']
summary:
Dee Brillenburg Wurth retired early from the United Nation where she was the Senior Child Protection Advisor to three Peacekeeping Missions in Burundi, Afghanistan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). 
Her responsibilities included advising mission leadership, Government and Non-state actors on issues relating to children in armed conflict, monitoring and reporting on grave child rights violations, and building the capacity of local actors to stop and prevent child recruitment and sexual abuse. She has worked to mitigate the impact of armed conflicts on children for more 25 years. 

Among her achievements in the DRC is the release of more than 3,000 children through direct face to face negotiation with armed group leaders in North and South Kivu, between 2018 and 2020, meeting the warlords on their own territory.  These meetings led to irreversible change, as 29 of the 31 rebel leaders that Dee met reportedly did not recruit any girls or boys after the negotiations.

Before joining the United Nations Dee worked for a number of international NGOâ€™s in other war-affected countries, including Kosovo, Albania, Sri Lanka, Sierra Leone, Ivory Coast, Senegal, Guinea and East Timor. Her main areas of interest are prevention, rehabilitation and reintegration of child soldiers, child rights promotion through media (TV, radio and print) and advocacy. 

In 1999 Dee wrote a 10-part drama series for Young Asia television (YA TV) which included topics such as child soldiers, slavery, HIV/AIDS, sex tourism, the caste system, arranged marriages and child suicide. YA TV is an English speaking channel, reaching 200 million young viewers in Sri Lanka, Nepal, India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. 

Before embarking on a career in war zones, Dee was a soap writer in the Netherlands.

summary:
I aspire to be a leader and an explorer within the field of wildlife conservation. Living abroad for 20 years, in a country with a different social, cultural, economic, and environmental context and values, has encouraged me to explore and gain a better understanding of the conservation problems at hand. This background I believe, has allowed me to view conservation situations in a broader and more open-minded way, and continues to motivate me to explore the various ontologies that exist in how conservation is viewed and carried out, in order to find ways and solutions that would benefit both people and nature.

I feel driven by purpose, curiosity, passion, commitment, dedication, and the drive to create change by spearheading conservation action through science and public engagement. I believe sharing stories in tandem with scientific research, experiences, and photography and film, has the power to enhance our collective awareness of the beauty of nature but it also exposes the harsh realities and the catastrophic problems at hand in the field of conservation. I believe, however, that at the fork of the dichotomy, lies a void that is to be filled by inspiring and creative ideas and solutions. A void, that not only encourages a new way of thinking, but a void that also encourages us to reflect and to rekindle our connection with ourselves and with nature, thereby bringing about concrete change. I hope to inspire and engage other young conservationists, whilst giving a voice to nature and wildlife and in so doing, propelling conservation research and solutions for the betterment of humanity, and nature.

summary:
My name is Eva de Vries (1984), and since November 1st 2021 I am working as foreign news editor (Radio, TV & Online) at Dutch public broadcaster NOS.

From February 2016 until September 2020 I worked as freelance multimedia journalist in East Africa, first based in Nairobi, Kenya and from 2018 onwards based in Kigali, Rwanda. I worked for Dutch as well as for English language media. Besides my journalism work, I did quite some communication & storytelling assignments for ngoâ€™s as well (text, photography, video and audio production). To see my work please visit www.storiesbyeva.com.

Prior to my move to Africa, I worked as a project coordinator for Movies that Matter (initiated by Amnesty International) (2014 â€“ 2016) and as an editor, producer and program coordinator for media organisation Lokaalmondiaal (2009 â€“ 2014). Leading the â€˜International Journalismâ€™ department, I developed and coordinated projects related to media, journalism, foreign correspondents and press freedom.

Education wise, from 2003 until 2009, I studied Journalism, International Relations and Political History (BA) and Conflict Studies and Human Rights (MA). During my Bachelor degree, I studied African History at the University of the Western Cape in Cape Town, South Africa. My research for my Master thesis took place in the border region of South Sudan, Northern Kenya and Northern Uganda. The years after, I travelled to Zambia, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Tanzania, Togo, Ghana, Egypt, Morocco, Zimbabwe Ethiopia and Rwanda.

Contact me at eva.de.vries@nos.nl

She is furthermore a member of the Team of Experts of the UKâ€™s Preventing Sexual Violence in Conflict Initiative (PSVI). From 2008-2019 she was a Research Fellow with the International Victimology Institute Tilburg (INTERVICT), from 2008-2016 an Associate Professor in international criminal law at Tilburg University, and from 2006-2007 an Associate Legal Officer at the NGO Womenâ€™s Initiatives for Gender Justice in The Hague. 

Her main areas of research, teaching and interest include international criminal law and procedure, victimsâ€™ rights, gender, victimology, conflict-related sexual violence, human trafficking and transitional justice. De Brouwer is the author of over 70 publications, including the book/PhD â€œSupranational Criminal Prosecution of Sexual Violence: The ICC and the Practice of the ICTY and the ICTR (Oxford-Antwerp: Intersentia, 2005)â€, for which she received the Max van der Stoel Human Rights Award 2006. Other (co-edited) works include â€œThe Men Who Killed Me: Rwandan Survivors of Sexual Violence (Douglas & McIntyre, 2009), â€œSexual Violence as an International Crime: Interdisciplinary Approaches (Intersentia, 2013), â€œELGAR Companion to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (Edward Elgar Publishing Ltd, 2016)â€, and "And I Live On: The Resilience of Rwandan Genocide Survivors of Sexual Violence (Wolf Legal Publishers, 2019)".

As an Engineering Improvement Lead at Thales Nederland, I'm responsible for driving innovation and process improvement across our engineering teams. With several years of experience in the aerospace and defence sectors, I'm passionate about finding new ways to optimize our engineering processes and ensure the delivery of high-quality products that meet our customers' needs.

In addition to my work at Thales Nederland, I'm also the Founder and Administrator for the Andalusian Machining Network. This group is dedicated to connecting machinists from Andalusia with the rest of the world, sharing knowledge, experiences, and best practices, and fostering collaboration and networking opportunities. As the founder and community administrator, I'm responsible for creating and managing the group's activities, ensuring that members follow the rules, and creating a welcoming environment for all members.

Furthermore, I'm pursuing a PhD in Artificial Intelligence applied to Last Mile Logistics using Drones at Universidad de Sevilla. This research involves developing algorithms and models to optimize the use of drones in the last-mile delivery process, with the goal of improving efficiency, reducing costs, and enhancing the overall customer experience.

In addition to my professional pursuits, I'm also deeply committed to volunteering and giving back. I've worked as a mentor for college students in Rwanda, helping them prepare for their first career job, and as a coding teacher and school support for youth at risk of exclusion. I've also volunteered my time teaching Spanish to refugees, helping them learn the language and adapt to their new home.

On top of these pursuits, I'm also a writer and recently published my first book, called "NO dejes la carrera de ingenierÃ­a". This book is aimed at helping engineering students overcome common obstacles and stay motivated throughout their studies. I'm thrilled to have this opportunity to share my knowledge and experiences with the next generation of engineers.

With my diverse background in engineering, management, research, writing, volunteering, and entrepreneurship, I bring a unique perspective and set of skills to every project and initiative I'm involved in. Whether I'm working to drive innovation and process improvement at Thales Nederland, managing and growing the Andalusian Machining Network community, pursuing my research interests in AI and logistics, volunteering to help others, or writing and sharing my insights with the world, I'm always looking for new challenges and opportunities to make a positive impact.

Passionate about a broad range of themes related to responsible natural resource management, nature conservation and sustainable production & consumption patterns attached to it. About making it possible, through research, start-ups/scale-ups and (impact) investments. 

My current work focus is on scaling enterprises active in the WASH sector and increasing their impact. I do this within my position at Aqua for All as Technical Assistance (TA) Manager for the Impact-Linked Fund for Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (ILF for WASH), a follow-up the â€˜Social Impact Incentives (SIINC) for WASHâ€™ programme. In this role, I'm responsible for designing and managing all TA activities that are part of ILF for WASH. The full focus of the TA is on Impact Measurement & Management (IMM) and Investment Readiness (IR). 

ILF for WASH is co-designed and implemented by Aqua for All and our partner Roots of Impact. The purpose is to provide (financial) rewards to enterprises that create (more/better/faster) positive social and environmental impact (additionality). The payments are based on the achievement of pre-defined outcomes and incentivise enterprises to further deepen their impact whilst, at the same time, enabling them to raise private investment and scale. In other words, the enterprise receives â€œbetter terms for better impactâ€.

My added value lies in my broad view and empathy, my analytic attitude, writing and presentation skills, and in my approach to relation & stakeholder management. 

I have the ability to quickly put information in the right context, smoothly coordinate projects, I work thoroughly with a great eye for detail, am flexible and I master three languages (Native Dutch, Full Professional English and Limited Working Spanish). summary:
Dr. Robert HeinschÂ is an Associate Professor of Public International Law at the Grotius Centre for International Legal Studies of Leiden University, and is the Director of its Kalshoven-Gieskes Forum on International Humanitarian Law at Leiden University and the founder of the Leiden IHL clinic. 

From 1 April 2018 to 28 February 2019, he held the DAAD Guest Chair for International Humanitarian Law, International Criminal Law and Applied Legal Theory at the Institute of Peace and Armed Conflict (IFHV) of Bochum University in Germany. During his time at the IFHV he successfully created the Bochum IHL Clinic. Furthermore, he served as Rapporteur of the ILA study group on the â€œThe Conduct of Hostilities under International Humanitarian Law â€“ Challenges from 21st Century Warfareâ€ between 2012 and 2017. 

Furthermore, he is member of the German National IHL Committee, and held the position of Federal Dissemination Officer for International Humanitarian Law of the German Red Cross from 2011 to 2014. Previously, he has worked as a Legal Advisor in the International Humanitarian Law Department of the Red Cross Headquarters in Berlin, and as a Legal Officer in the Trial Chamber of the International Criminal Court in The Hague. In addition, he has been a Senior Research Fellow at the Chair for International Law and European Law, Cologne University, and a Visiting Lecturer at Bochum University, respectively.

My 15 years of experience helping banks and mobile networks implement complex payment technologies lead me to realize my knowledge is repetitive in nature and ready for automation. This eventually lead to the creation of ExpertBox.com, which makes knowledge automation accessible to all.

ExpertBox.com is a free knowledge automation platform enabling experts to automate, monetize and share their knowledge using simple drag and drop logic, real-time data and machine learning.
